title: Developing and refining methods for comparative cross-national research on poverty and vulnerability: Drawing on Young Lives' and WeD's experiences
abstractText:
The grant will enable methodological and logistical lessons learnt from the experiences of two comparative cross-national studies of poverty and vulnerability in developing countries: Young Lives, and the Wellbeing in Developing Countries ESRC research group, to be communicated through a range of media. The outputs include an online toolkit, NCRM review paper, journal special issues, edited methodological volume, and training and capacity building.

This grant will also develop and administer a cross-nationally comparative module to capture young people's social and cultural competencies or non-cognitive skills, which could potentially be included in surveys and impact evaluations. The module will be accompanied by guidelines to enable reliable adaptation in other developing countries and there will be a qualitative component exploring emic understandings of social and cultural competencies and critically examining the concepts implicit in existing measures.

These outputs will benefit researchers and policy makers who want to monitor and understand the multidimensional effects of material poverty on the wellbeing of children and adults.
impactText: Considerable progress has been made on the main objective of the grant, which is to share methodological learning from the use of mixed-methods research in contexts of poverty and vulnerability in developing countries. Areas addressed by the grant include enhancing measures of poverty and methods for impact evaluation and increasing understanding of poverty dynamics, for example, by developing a measure of non-cognitive skills for use with young people and a protocol for the adaptation of similar measures in developing countries (the use of cognitive debriefing techniques will be discussed in a paper to be drafted early 2015; it also informed an ESRC grant application to develop a survey measure of capabilities for use in India and other developing countries). The work funded by the grant feeds into broader trends, for example, a growing interest in mixed methods and interdisciplinary studies to address complex social problems and evaluate the impact of interventions. I continue to work with colleagues at UEA on impact evaluation short courses and masters programme and in co-authoring 'Impact Evaluation for International Development: The Essential Guide' which will be published by Routledge in 2015. I have provided impact evaluation training to Uganda government officials (funded by GIZ) and have provide training to DFID evaluation officers on the evaluation of small n interventions, building on a new short course I delivered in June 2014 with Maren Duvendack. I am also collaborating with the new DFID-funded Centre for Development Impact http://www.ids.ac.uk/cdi, which UEA has become one of the partners of, and have co-organised two events on ethics in impact evaluation (September 2014 and January 2015).
